title: Big 12 power rankings: All eyes on Oklahoma, Texas as Red River Showdown looms
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg breaks down the latest Amway Coaches Poll. USA TODAY

Saturday is what we’ve been waiting for.

After rain and lightning delays, while watching a Big 12 back soar to the top of the nation’s rushing statistics, after listening to Mike Gundy blow up about the Internet one week and at a reporter the next ...

Yes, it’s time for another Red River Showdown.

Finally, the best two teams in this conference will clash — Oklahoma against Texas on Saturday at the Cotton Bowl.

They’ve been atop the weekly Power Ratings all season, and they’ll likely be there at this time next week, as well.

But will Lincoln Riley’s Sooners continue No. 1?

Or will Tom Herman’s bunch replace them?

Oklahoma running back Trey Sermon avoids a tackle attempt by the Texas defense during their game at the Cotton Bowl in 2018. (Photo: Tim Heitman, USA TODAY Sports)

Who wins the quarterback battle, Oklahoma’s Heisman contender Jalen Hurts, or Texas’ Sam Ehlinger?

Set your recording device if you can’t watch it live. It promises to be a dandy.

Here's the Week 7 Big Power Rankings:

No. 1 Oklahoma (5-0, 2-0 Big 12)

Last week’s ranking: 1

Last weekend: Defeated Kansas 45-20.

In a nutshell: It’s doubtful that Jalen Hurts will be rattled while playing in Saturday’s Red River Showdown. He faced Auburn in the annual Alabama-Auburn Iron Bowl, so playing against Texas Saturday in Dallas isn’t likely to elicit a bunch of pre-game nervousness. For what it’s worth, the Alabama transfer completed 40 of 59 passes for 451 yards and four touchdowns in three Iron Bowls.

On deck: Saturday vs. Texas, noon ET, Fox.

POWER RANKINGS: ACC | Big 12 | Big Ten | Pac-12 | SEC

RE-RANK: Ohio State takes over as the latest No. 1 in NCAA Re-Rank 1-130

WINNERS AND LOSERS: Highs and lows from Week 6 in college football

No. 2 Texas (4-1, 2-0)

Last week’s ranking: 2

Last weekend: Defeated West Virginia 42-31.

In a nutshell: Saturday’s four-interception game could bode well for the Longhorns, who are 14-2 under Tom Herman when forcing multiple turnovers. Ehlinger, the Big 12’s second-best quarterback, must be good at keeping possessions alive and keeping the Sooner’s high-octane offense on the sidelines. It’s an offense that’s averaging a nation’s-leading 643.8 yards and 53.4 points a game.

On deck: Saturday vs. Oklahoma, noon, Fox.

No. 3 Baylor (5-0, 2-0)

Last week’s ranking: 4

Last weekend: Defeated Kansas State 31-12.

In a nutshell: Underrated team led by underrated quarterback. Baylor and Charlie Brewer are proving doubters wrong, while showing the Big 12 world that the Bears are no flash in the pan. Winning by double-figures at Kansas State was impressive, and Saturday, Matt Rhule’s team has another chance to do big things against the team that just knocked off Oklahoma State.

On deck: Saturday vs. Texas Tech, 4 p.m., FS1.

No. 4 Iowa State (3-2, 1-1)

Last week’s ranking: 6

Last weekend: Defeated TCU 49-24.

In a nutshell: The Cyclones roll as quarterback Brock Purdy rolls. Against what’s usually a very good TCU defense Saturday, the sophomore had an impressive 349 yards of offense – 247 on completions to 10 receivers, and 102 on a dozen rushes. It’s safe to speculate that coaches will wind him up every game, because he’s not only the Cyclones’ best quarterback, but also the best rushing threat.

On deck: Saturday at West Virginia, 4 p.m., ESPN.

No. 5 Texas Tech (3-2, 1-1)

Last week’s ranking: 9

Last weekend: Defeated Oklahoma State 45-35.

In a nutshell: Fans wondered with concern when Matt Wells named Jett Duffey the starting quarterback while Alan Bowman recovered from injury. All he did Saturday, was complete 26 of 44 passes for 424 yards and four touchdowns.

On deck: Saturday at Baylor, 4 p.m., FS1.

No. 6 Oklahoma State (4-2, 1-2)

Last week’s ranking: 3

Last weekend: Lost to Texas Tech 45-35.

In a nutshell: At least Chuba Hubbard continued playing all right, the nation’s top rusher adding 156 more yards on 36 carries to his impressive stats. Other than that? Nothing. Quarterback Spencer Sanders threw three interceptions and fumbled twice, then told reporters: “Not the offensive line, not the receivers, not the defense. I did. Spencer Sanders had five turnovers. I’ve just got to do better.” There’s some cleaning up to do before returning to the field against Baylor.

On deck: Oct. 19 vs. Baylor.

No. 7 West Virginia (3-2, 1-1)

Last week’s ranking: 8

Last weekend: Lost to Texas 42-31.

In a nutshell: Quarterback Austin Kendall is still a bit of a work in progress, after throwing four interceptions in a nonetheless close game. He’s thrown seven interceptions this season, and he’s preparing this week to face an Iowa State pass defense that’s at time shaky. Kendall, however, kept the Mountaineers close with 31-of-46 passing for 367 yards and three touchdowns.

On deck: Saturday vs. Iowa State, 4 p.m., ESPN.

No. 8 TCU (3-2, 1-1)

Last week’s ranking: 5

Last weekend: Lost to Iowa State 49-24.

In a nutshell: In case you missed it, here’s what coach Gary Patterson said after Iowa State beat his team in all ways Saturday: “They kicked our butts. Every phase, pretty simple. Not much more you can say.” TCU came into the game averaging 275.2 rushing yards, but managed just 63, before forced into second-half comeback passing mode.

On deck: Oct. 19 at Kansas State.

No. 9 Kansas State (3-2, 0-2)

Last week’s ranking: 7

Last weekend: Lost to Baylor 31-12.

In a nutshell: The Wichita Eagle named punter Devin Anctil Kansas State’s MVP after a second Big 12 double-figure loss in a row last Saturday. He was very good on a day when his teammates weren’t. It’s been tough going after a 3-0 non-conference start included an upset win at Mississippi State. The offense has averaged just 12.5 points in Big 12 losses against Baylor and Oklahoma State. The defense has given up an average of 28.5. Chris Klieman’s team has a bye week in which to figure stuff out.

On deck: Oct. 19 vs. TCU.

No. 10 Kansas (2-4, 0-3)

Last week’s ranking: 10

Last weekend: Lost to Oklahoma 45-20.

In a nutshell: You could see this one coming, coach Les Miles’ Sunday firing of offensive coordinator Les Koenning. Take away the Jayhawks’ 48-24 victory at Boston College, and Kansas has averaged just 17.8 points. That’s not cutting it in the high-scoring Big 12, so it’s starting over with Brent Dearmon, who Miles promoted from senior offensive analyst. “Brent is one of the brightest individuals I have encountered in all my years of coaching,” said Miles, whose 16 seasons as a college coach include stops at Oklahoma State and LSU, where his team won the 2011 national title. Dearmon was the head coach at NAIA Bethel University last season.

On deck: Oct. 19 at Texas.
description: Baylor and Iowa State ticked up this week in the Big 12 power rankings as eyes now turn to Oklahoma and Texas meeting in the Cotton Bowl.
